What Are React Components?

React components are the building blocks of a React application.
Each component represents a small, independent, and reusable part of the user interface â€” like buttons, forms, menus, or entire pages.

You can think of them like LEGO pieces:
each one is self-contained, but together they create a full, interactive application.

ğŸ§  Main Ideas

Reusability â€“ A component can be used in many places without rewriting it.
Example: one "Button" component might appear on several screens.

Modularity â€“ The app is split into small, manageable pieces instead of one big file.
This makes it easier to maintain and understand.

Composition â€“ Components can contain other components.
For instance, a "Page" component might include a "Header", "Sidebar", and "Footer".

Data Flow â€“ Data usually flows from parent to child through something called props (short for properties).
This allows customization of each component's behavior and appearance.

State Management â€“ Components can have their own state, meaning they can remember information, react to user actions, and update the screen automatically.

Declarative Nature â€“ Instead of manually changing the page, you describe what the UI should look like at any moment, and React updates it for you.

Lifecycle â€“ Each component has a "life cycle": it is created, updated when data changes, and removed when no longer needed.

ğŸ’¡ Why Components Are Powerful

They make development faster and cleaner.

They encourage consistent design and logic.

They simplify debugging and testing.

They enable teamwork â€” different developers can work on different components.
